indicators.justification:
The State Statistic Service publishes aggregated emission data once a year on its website (1). 

Updated ecology data is available due to civil society and private sector efforts such as SavaEcoBot (2) or Lun (3). However, they mainly cover only air pollution and some cities. 
Also, according to the TAPAS report on ecology data impact (4), among 99 data sets required for publication following the Open Data Decree, concerning 19 environmental spheres, as of October 2020 on the Open Data Porta were published 33 datasets, which is 33%. 

As an expert on ecology data mentioned, there are no actions from the governmental side to open ecology, emission data, even in their strategic documents. Only these private initiatives provide data to citizens. (5)

Source (Accessed 03 August 2021): 

(1) Emmission statistic data: http://www.ukrstat.gov.ua/operativ/operativ2018/ns/vzap/arch_vzrap_u.htm
(2) SaveEcoBot (CSO): https://www.saveecobot.com/
(3) Lun portal (private sector): https://misto.lun.ua/air
(4) Report on ecology data impact: https://tapas.org.ua/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Ecology-OD-Impact-Study.pdf
(5) Interview with en expert, ecology startup CEO, 03/08/2021.

indicators.justification:
The State Business Registered  (company) data and is available online as open data (1). It is timely, but with low quality, sometimes inaccurate, 27% of companies didn't provide data about their beneficial owners (2). 

The State Business Register is also available via paid API (3), and almost all data is available for free as a service via web-service (4). 
Open Data Portal provides data with law quality. Data, available on the Open Data Portal, is with broken XML, there is a need to work on this dataset to fix it before the use.

There was a court case to open up all company data. So the government published only 1/3 of data they collected about companies. Other data were available via paid API. The court decided that it violates the Access to Public Information Law and Open Data Decree. So in December 2019 the state business register was published almost entirely (5). 

Data, available on the Open Data Portal, is with broken XML, there is a need to work on this dataset to fix it before the use.

Sources (Accessed 1 August 2021)
(1) The State Business Register: https://data.gov.ua/dataset/1c7f3815-3259-45e0-bdf1-64dca07ddc10

indicators.justification:
Health care data about facilities, near real-time data in Ukraine, has been almost unavailable until COVID (1). The Ministry of Health doesn't publish relevant open data on the Open Data Portal besides outdated aggregated statistics (2). The government launched the covid portal in spring 2020 and started to publish data about COVID (3) but not about the general situation in hospitals. The National Health Service publishes data about some issues of the health care system and COVID on their portals and the Open Data portal (4). At the end of 2020, the National Security Council of Ukraine launched their portal and dashboard to collect and present data from the Information System "Meddata" and present as analytical panels (download function is not working correctly) data about COVID-related topics, hospitals. (5).    

Sources: (Accessed 03 August 2021)
(1) Data and COVID discussion: https://www.facebook.com/watch/live/?extid=SEO----&v=540160150193605&ref=watch_permalink
(2) Ministry of Health page on the Open Data Portal: https://data.gov.ua/organization/7daccc8b-6a54-4d15-a953-deb458202dca
(3) COVID governmental portal: https://covid19.gov.ua/
(4) The National Health Service portal and data: https://nszu.gov.ua/e-data
(5) The National Security Council portal and data: https://health-security.rnbo.gov.ua/

indicators.justification:
The land use data is partly available on the open data land portal (1) and via API (2). It is also available as a service for citizens via public land cadastre map (3). The cadastre codes, numbers are unique identifiers for land plots. Although a list of data from the Public Land Cadastre should be published according to legislation (4), only part of required and needed data is available (5). There is also a problem with available geospatial data quality as only centroids are available via API, not pivot points (6). 

Sources (accessed 1-27 July 2021)
(1) Open Data Land Portal: https://data.land.gov.ua/
(2) Access via API: https://e.land.gov.ua/
(3) The State Public Cadastre Map: https://map.land.gov.ua/?cc=3461340.1719504707,6177585.367221659&z=6.5&l=pcm_forest,kadastr&bl=ortho10k_all
(4) The National GeoSpatial Data Infrastructure Law: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/554-20?fbclid=IwAR16-8STmNRUn0Gb-roGlKGyhFXXpDeatMdon7wwFX87qVkVUpZ88nFeQuc#Text
(5) API description: https://e.land.gov.ua/api/doc, data structure: https://data.land.gov.ua/
(6) Interview with an expert (anonimus), 27 July 2021: "There is no actual and reliable cadastre codes available, no pivot points, coordinates, no data about land status in land data (is it leased or privatized)".

indicators.justification:
Even though land data is mostly available on the State Land Cadastre Map as a service for citizens and the State GeoCadastre is its data holder (1), data about land tenure are available as paid service or API by the Ministry of Justice state enterprise "The National Information Systems" (2). To have access to land tenure data, users have to sign a contract with the National Information Systems State Enterprise and receive the right to use from 5 000 to 750 000 queries via API (3). In addition, data is also available as a paid service for all users to get information about specific land tenure records (4). 

Land tenure data are not geospatial, but users can combine it with the land cadastre data via cadastre code, and coordinates can be extracted (5). 

According to the State Land Cadastre audit, data about five mln ha (its landowners) is missing and will be updated only after digitizing paper data (6). It can cause the problem that not all data are available via paid API.    

Sources (accessed 27 July 2021) 
(1) Land Cadastre Data: https://data.land.gov.ua/
(2) API documentation (in Ukrainian): https://nais.gov.ua/files/general/2020/05/28/20200528191932-71.docx
(3) Draft agreement on access to API of the State Register of Real Rights https://nais.gov.ua/files/general/2021/07/05/20210705203344-39.pdf
(4) Service for all users for specific records search: https://kap.minjust.gov.ua/services?product_id=1
(5) Land Cadastre Data: https://data.land.gov.ua/
(6) The National Agency on Corruption Prevention Report about land: https://nazk.gov.ua/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Ryzyky_pryvatyzatsiya_2011.pdf

indicators.justification:
According to the Open Budget Survey (the latest 2019), Ukraine has 63% budget transparency (1). There is going to be OBS 2021. But they have promised to publish it soon (2). 

There are some details about the availability of some data in the questionnaire to this survey (3). The budget classification is mostly developed based on international standards (4). Data on extra budget funds is partly available.

Meanwhile, data about budgets are allocated in different formats and sources, primarily in bad-quality tables. Only spending data is of good level quality, provide access to data via API (5). Other budget data is collected and presented on the Open Budget service, but not all data is there (6)

Sources (Accessed 1-8 August 2021): 

(1) Open Budget Survey 2019: Ukraine: https://www.internationalbudget.org/open-budget-survey/country-results/2019/ukraine
(2) OBS 2021 plan: http://www.ipp-jcs.org/en/open-budget-survey-2/
(3) Open Budget Survey country questionnaire Ukraine: https://www.internationalbudget.org/sites/default/files/2020-05/ukraine-202002150030.pdf
(4) Budget Codex: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2456-17
(5) Spending: https://confluence.spending.gov.ua/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=65547
(6) Open Budget: https://openbudget.gov.ua/

indicators.justification:
The e-procuring system Prozorro was launched in Ukraine in 2016 (1). Prozorro won the prestigious World Procurement Award and the annual prize of the Open Government Awards in 2016. In addition, Prozorro has been recognized by the World Bank and is a showcase for their Open Contracting Partnership (2). Prozorro was developed based on open source and open data principles, OCD standards (3). Data are available via API, free of charge (4). Meanwhile, COVID influenced procurement data availability because COVID procurement was taken out of the system Prozorro. Only reports were published and available in the system (as open data via API). (5)

indicators.justification:
in Ukraine, the Open Data initiative on the governmental level was launched after the legislation on Access to Public Information amendment when public information in open data format was defined (1). The government later adopted the Open Data Decree, the Open Data Roadmap, and the process was initiated, open data portal launched (2). Open Data initiative received another boost after the USAID/UKAID international technical support project TAPAS launch at the end of 2017. A lot of project resources were allocated for policy development, communication to open up data, open data challenges, etc. (3). 

The Ministry of Digital Transformation is responsible for open data policy development and implementation (4). The open data expert group is working in the Ministry on open data issues (5). 4,4 mln UAH budget money was allocated for the Open Data Portal support and development as of 2021. (6). 

Sources: (Accessed 1-29 July 2021)
(1) The Access to Public Information Law: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2939-17#Text
(2) The Open Data Portal: https://data.gov.ua/

(4) The Ministry of Digital Transformation: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/856-2019-%D0%BF
(5) Part of the open data expert governmental team: https://diia.data.gov.ua/team
(6) The Ministry of Digital Transformation Budget 2021 https://thedigital.gov.ua/storage/uploads/files/page/community/budget/%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82_%D0%B1%D1%8E%D0%B4%D0%B6%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%96%CC%88_%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B8_%D0%BD%D0%B0_2021_%D1%80%D1%96%D0%BA_2901030.pdf

indicators.justification:
Open data policy requires regulations and rules and good data infrastructure and data use (demand). The Access to Public Information law makes all data holders (national or local) publish open data (1). In some cities, local administrations' legal acts about open data policy, regulations were adopted, open data portals were launched. (2). But law and policy implementation, data quality varies from local administration to local administration (3). Only a small number of local councils organize or cooperate with local NGOs to organize hackathons to boost published open data use. (4, 5). 

There is a requirement of law to publish open data on the Open Data portal: https://data.gov.ua/. There are also open data local portals developed (not full list): Lviv https://opendata.city-adm.lviv.ua/ Chernivtsi: https://data.city.cv.ua/

indicators.justification:
The Open Data Competency Center was launched in May 2021 In Ukraine (1). This Center was created and supported by the Ministry of Digital Transformation with the support of international organizations and projects (2). According to their numbers, as of June 2021, more than 38 000 people participated in the training. In addition, special training for public servants was conducted (the first phase coverage - more than 500 public servants). (3). There are also series of educational courses on Open Data (for public servants as well) are available on the Digital education platform (4). 

There are mostly legal, managemental, political, and organizational questions covered by courses, almost no technical topics or data analysis. (5)

In cooperation with USAID/UKAID TAPAS project, the Open Data Leaders Network program for selected public servants from national and local levels was implemented. (6)

indicators.justification:
Beneficial ownership information collection and publication are required by Articles 6 and 9 of the Unified State Business Register Law (1).  The requirement to publish information from the Unified State Business Register with BO data that is part of the Register is required by the Open Data Decree (2). Definitions comprehensively cover ownership. According to article 1 of the Antimoney laundering legislation, the definition covers direct and indirect influence on the company (3). According to article 1 of the Anti-money laundering legislation (4), a sign of direct, decisive influence on the activity is the direct ownership by a natural person of a share in the amount of not less than 25 percent of the authorized (composed) capital or voting rights of a legal entity. Signs of indirect decisive influence on the activity are at least the possession by a natural person of a share in the amount of no less than 25 percent of the authorized (composed) capital or voting rights of a legal entity through related entities. But, according to the Anticorruption Action Centre research, beneficial ownership data is often inaccurate, not complete, and low quality. (5) 

Sources: (Accessed 22 July 2021)

(1)  The Unified State Business Register Law: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/755-15#n160
(2) The Open Data Decree https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/835-2015-%D0%BF#Text
(3) The Antimoney laundering law: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/361-20#n52 
(4) The Antimoney laundering law: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/361-20#n52 
(5) Beneficial ownership data in Ukraine: https://project.liga.net/projects/beneficiar/index_en.html

indicators.justification:
The data sharing in Ukraine is legally framed on the government level by governmental Decrees (1). There is a draft of the law on e-registers, but it is not adopted yet (2). Ukraine also joined the ISA2 program to implement EIF principles but there is no data about its implementation (3).

The data-sharing platform Trembita was launched in 2019 and now has more than 70 bodies in there (4). The new law on paperless public service can become a breakthrough for public bodies on national and local levels to implement e-interaction, data sharing processes with other governmental bodies (5).

indicators.justification:
The primary Personal Data Protection law was adopted in 2010 in Ukraine (1) based on old European Directives and practices (2). This legislation provides a framework for personal data subjects' rights and data holder obligations; it applies across the country and all sectors. The Parliament Commissionaire on Human Rights is responsible for personal data protection oversight, and people can apply to the Commissionaire to protect their rights (3). The Commissionaire on Human Rights developed regulations about personal data processing, sensitive data (4). However, the framework doesn't provide substantial protection of location-related data or protection and awareness of algorithmic decision-making (5). The framework is outdated and needs to be harmonized with the GDPR (6). This is why the new law draft based on discussions and GDPR rules was registered in the parliament in June 2021 (7). 

Source (Links accessed 1-27 July 2021)

(1) The Personal Data Protection Law: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2297-17
(2) Interview with Vlad Nekrutenko, co-founder of PrivacyHub, GDPR expert
(3) The Personal Data Protection Law, Article 22: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2297-17
(4) Typical procedure for processing personal data developed by the Parliament Commissionaire on Human Rights: http://zakon5.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/v1_02715-14?test=n6HMfJRw7UpVmUn6ZilPzapnHI41gs80msh8Ie6#n11
(5) Procedure for notifying the Parliament Commissioner for Human Rights about the processing of personal data, which poses a special risk to the rights and freedoms of personal data subjects, about the structural unit or responsible person organizing work related to personal data protection during their processing, as well as the disclosure of such information: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/v1_02715-14/print1443613185179245#n215 
(6) Interview with Vlad Nekrutenko, co-founder of PrivacyHub, GDPR expert
(7) New draft of the law on personal data protection was registered in June 2021, discussed in 2019-2020: https://w1.c1.rada.gov.ua/pls/zweb2/webproc4_1?pf3511=72160 based on GDPR

indicators.justification:
There are no specific laws, regulations, policies, and guidance that require that data collection and publication processes be available in the country's official or national language. Still, there is a general legislative framework for ensuring the functioning of the Ukrainian language as the state language (1). The Law was adopted in 2019. It requires using the state language (Ukrainian) in regulations, administrative work, and document management in the Law (Article 13). This Law also amends other legal acts, such as "The order of coverage of the activity of public authorities and local governments in Ukraine by mass media" where article 4 was amended (2). According to the Law on ensuring the functioning of the Ukrainian language as the state language, the language for sharing information on the activities of public authorities and local governments shall be done in Ukrainian and other languages. The governmental order also requires that all information on the official website (web portal) should be provided in Ukrainian, as well as, if necessary, in English and the languages of national minorities. (3)

Sources: (Accessed 1-29 July 2021)
(1) The Law on ensuring the functioning of the Ukrainian language as the state language: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2704-19/print
(2) The Law on the order of coverage of the activity of public authorities and local governments in Ukraine by mass media: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/539/97-%D0%B2%D1%80#Text 
(3) Governmental Order on publishing information about the public authorities on the Internet: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/3-2002-%D0%BF#Text

indicators.justification:
Ukrainian laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for generating and publishing public information in an open data format. The Access to Public Information law was amended in 2015 and includes public information in open data format definition, the specific of use and re-use of open data, obligations for data holders, and rights for data users (1). According to the Open Data Maturity Report 2020, Moldova, the UK, and Ukraine have an open data policy framework in their country, including an action
plan with measures to be implemented in the field of open data. In addition, the UK and Ukraine also
have an open data strategy in place (2). There are almost no specific official international data standards except for OCD4IDS and DCAT-AP standards for metadata in Ukraine (3). Training and capacity-building activities are promoted by the Open Data Strategy for 2018-2020 (4) and a new strategy with the same aspect are in the process of adoption (5). The Open Data Competences Center was launched in March 2021 (6). 
The assessed open data law, policies, and guidance cover the majority of localities and government agencies. According to the legislation all public information holders should provide data in open data format (7). 

Sources (links accessed 1-27 July 2021)
(1) The Access to Public Information Law: https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/2939-17

indicators.justification:
Campaing and party finance information is very complex. The Election Codex (1) and the Political Party law (2) require the collection and publication of this information. For example, in the Election Codex, depending on the type of elections requires to publish financial reports about the election funds, the National Agency on Corruption Prevention should publish all reports about parties. The problem is that the election funds report of the MP candidates from single member districts and candidates on local election are available only on the level of local election comissions and sometimes it is hard to get it as they are not always published or publicly available.  

There are different orders that requlate the structure of financial reports, different procedures and responsibilities for not doing that correctly or in time (3). 

Meanwhile published data are with very law quality and one should refine it and work a lot on making this data machine-readable, part of data is missing, part is not provided due to COVID (4).
